title: 103_s516
content: SEC. 2. DURABLE MEDICAL EQUIPMENT. The Social Security Act is referenced for amendments. Section 1861 is amended to include a definition for medical equipment and supplies. The term 'medical equipment and supplies' includes durable medical equipment, prosthetic devices, orthotics and prosthetics, home dialysis supplies, surgical dressings, immunosuppressive drugs, and other items as determined by the Secretary. Effective from January 1, 1994, national standards for suppliers of medical equipment and supplies will be developed and applied. The national standards for suppliers of medical equipment and supplies were established on January 1, 1994. A new subsection was added to Section 1834, requiring suppliers to meet these standards and possess a valid supplier number for payment under Medicare. The Secretary will revise these standards by January 1, 1996, in consultation with stakeholders. The national standards for suppliers of medical equipment and supplies were established on January 1, 1994, requiring compliance with State and Federal licensure, maintaining a physical facility, having liability insurance, and meeting other specified requirements. Beginning after December 31, 1995, suppliers must adhere to these revised standards. Beginning after December 31, 1995, suppliers of medical equipment and supplies must meet revised standards. Certificates of Medical Necessity must be standardized by the Secretary by July 1, 1994. Beginning after December 31, 1995, suppliers of medical equipment and supplies must meet revised standards. Certificates of Medical Necessity must be standardized by the Secretary by July 1, 1994. The standardized certificates must be completed by prescribing physicians and transmitted to the supplier and carrier for payment processing. Suppliers are prohibited from distributing certificates of medical necessity. Beginning after December 31, 1995, suppliers of medical equipment and supplies must meet revised standards. Certificates of Medical Necessity must be standardized by the Secretary by July 1, 1994. Suppliers are prohibited from distributing completed or partially completed certificates of medical necessity for commercial purposes, except for certain billing information. Suppliers of medical equipment and supplies must adhere to revised standards starting after December 31, 1995. Certificates of Medical Necessity must be standardized by the Secretary by July 1, 1994. Distributing a certificate of medical necessity with unauthorized information can result in a civil money penalty for the supplier. Suppliers distributing unauthorized certificates of medical necessity may face civil money penalties up to $1,000 per certificate. The term 'certificate of medical necessity' refers to a document required by the Secretary to demonstrate the need for a covered item for diagnosis, treatment, or improving bodily function. Amendments regarding these penalties are effective after December 31, 1995. The amendments regarding penalties for unauthorized certificates of medical necessity will apply to certificates issued on or after January 1, 1994. Section 1834 is amended to include new subsection (k) for developing national coverage criteria for 200 medical equipment and supplies by July 1, 1994. The Secretary will establish criteria for selecting medical equipment and supplies based on frequency of purchase by beneficiaries, medical necessity determinations, and coverage/utilization criteria. These criteria will be published for fiscal intermediaries and carriers without further publication requirements. The Secretary will annually review coverage and utilization criteria for medical equipment and supplies to ensure consistency among carriers. A report on the impact of uniform criteria on item utilization must be submitted by January 1, 1995. The House and Senate committees are analyzing the impact of uniform criteria on the use of medical equipment by enrollees. A new prohibition limits suppliers to one number unless necessary for identification purposes. The amendment clarifies that inducements as kickbacks do not include certain tasks in contract supply arrangements between skilled nursing facilities and suppliers of medical supplies and equipment. Effective from July 1, 1994. The amendment clarifies that certain tasks in contract supply arrangements between skilled nursing facilities and suppliers of medical supplies and equipment are not considered kickbacks. Effective from January 1, 1994, limitations on beneficiary liability are outlined for suppliers of medical equipment and supplies. The amendment clarifies that suppliers are responsible for expenses incurred for items and services furnished to individuals on an unassigned basis. The individual is not financially responsible for these expenses unless informed in advance by the supplier. Effective from July 1, 1994, the amendment applies to items or services provided after this date. The amendment to Section 1834 of the Social Security Act specifies changes in payment for durable medical equipment, focusing on ventilators and IPPB machines. Payment for supplies related to nebulizers and aspirators is also addressed, ensuring payment in accordance with specific guidelines. The amendment to Section 1834 of the Social Security Act addresses payment for ostomy supplies, tracheostomy supplies, urologicals, surgical dressings, and other medical supplies, effective from January 1, 1994. Payment will be made in accordance with specific guidelines outlined in the amendment. The amendment to Section 1834 of the Social Security Act, effective from January 1, 1994, applies to items furnished on or after that date, with exceptions for surgical dressings and medical supplies supplied on or after July 1, 1994. Additionally, there is a freeze in reasonable charges for parenteral and enteral nutrients, supplies, and equipment during 1994. During 1994, payments under part B of title XVIII of the Social Security Act for parenteral and enteral nutrients, supplies, and equipment are capped at 1993 levels. The Comptroller General will conduct a study on services and supplies in nursing facilities by January 1, 1995. The Comptroller General will conduct a study on descriptions of medical equipment codes to determine accuracy and clarity, with recommendations for changes by January 1, 1995. The Comptroller General will conduct a study on medical equipment codes to improve accuracy and clarity, with recommendations for changes by January 1, 1995, including suggestions for additional improvements. The Comptroller General will conduct a study on medical equipment codes for accuracy and clarity, with recommendations for changes by January 1, 1995.
